data.title: Greg Kinnear Breaks Down His Most Iconic Characters
data.meta_description:
Greg Kinnear revisits his most iconic characters, including roles in As Good As It Gets, You've Got Mail, Sabrina, Auto Focus, Little Miss Sunshine, Brigsby Bear, Nurse Betty and House of Cards.
The final season of House of Cards is now on Netflix!
data.text:
Timer was the stand-in for Judy

so Timer would come in.

With me, c-c-come here, come here Verdell

and it'd just be perfect every single time

and then right before the cameras got set up

and the lights, they would say okay bring Judy in

and poor Timer would just look around and get swept off

the stage, she'd be like, wha, I can run circles around

this bitch, wait a second.

[upbeat music]

[Announcer] Simon Bishop, As Good As It Gets.

That was a script by Mark Andrews and Jim Brooks

that was off the charts great.

Still to this day one of the best scripts I ever read,

it was called Old Friends and Jim kept going no man,

I don't like the name, the name's terrible

and I was like, Jim, trust me, the name's great.

He was right, I was wrong.

As good as it gets was a line that Jack utters in the movie.

I was shooting another film up in San Francisco

and Jim Brooks and Francine Maisler actually came up

to visit me, you know, I read for 'em

and I kept just trying to pretend that Jack Nicholson

was not in the movie because I was too [chuckles]

I was just too big of a fan, it was too crazy

to think that I was getting close to doing a movie

with Jack, much less, when I got the call saying

okay Greg, we're gonna have you go over

to Jack's house tonight and just, you know,

read through some scenes.

Oh really?

That's it, huh?

Just go to Jack's house and read through some scenes.

It was terrifying.

Everything looks distorted and everything inside

just kind of aches and you can barely find

the will to complain.

Yeah, um, I'm glad we did this.

We shot the movie for a very, very long time

and I felt like Jim, who's such a brilliant artist,

was just searching for the sound,

he knew it so specifically, and I was a huge fan

of Broadcast News and Terms of Endearment.

He so didn't disappoint me in being the artist

that I knew he was and was so great at bringing

all of us, that whole cast, including Helen,

who's off the charts great, together in knowing

what we were all there to do.

He had a thing he was looking for and the more we shot,

the more it seemed to coalesce.

[Announcer] Frank Navasky, You've Got Mail,

well that was with Nora Ephron, the wonderful,

talented Nora, I cannot say enough about that woman.

Incredible writer and talented human being.

It was kind of based on a writer from The Observer

in New York that she knew.

The guy I was playing in it was,

he was a little bit of a nerd and it was great fun to play

because he was, he's definitely the guy

that doesn't get the girl.

When you got Tom in the movie and Meg,

it ain't goin' my way, ya know.

You don't love me.

[laughs]

Me either.

You don't love me?

I really liked Frank, he was a lovely little character

and I felt like I was just gonna make an observation

about something that would have been funny and amusing.

But I lost it.

Hold on.

It's giving me time to think about what I was going

to say about Frank, no, no, tool around with that

for a second, it still looks off to me,

I think the microphone, look at that.

I feel like that's not gonna work.

[crew laughing]

I worked with Michael Palin, the great Michael Palin,

one of my favorite actors dating back to Monty Python days,

was also in, people don't realize this,

'cause he ended up getting cut out of the movie, tragically,

because we had great stuff, Michael had a really funny role

in the movie and it just didn't pan out in the final story

but one of the great joys of the movie is a bunch of stuff

that ended up on the cutting room floor for me.

It was my work with Michael.

[Announcer] David Larrabee, Sabrina.

It was the first movie that I ever got cast in.

I was basically looking at clips of Jerry Springer

and Geraldo on a show called Talk Soup

and Sidney Pollack who's an amazing director,

producer and actor, damn, he's good, got a hold

of a tape from that show and brought me into his office

to talk to him about the role.

I had just thought he wanted me to come in there

'cause he couldn't believe anybody else was from

a smaller town than him in Indiana.

He was engaging and interesting and got me relaxed

then told me I'd be playing Harrison Ford's brother

which kind of killed the relaxation part of it.

I'm not ready to make this kind of commitment.

I see, she must have asked for an actual wedding date.

I don't know what came over me,

she was healing children, I was in a tuxedo,

I'm not in any position to take care of a wife.

Elizabeth is a doctor and a millionaire, David,

she won't be a burden.

We read through a few scenes and he had me come back

and eventually I got a call from my agent asking me

if I was sitting down.

I believe I was but he told me that I was gonna play

this role and it was a tricky movie to do

because obviously it's a beloved remake.

William Holden is certainly a beloved actor,

my mom was a big fan and I was taking on his role

and I kind of felt like this isn't real.

The set was very way crazy over the top

with always what seemed to be a thousand extras

and everybody sipping champagne both when we were rolling

and not rolling, it was all quite lovely

and it was a hell of a way to start.

[Announcer] Auto Focus, Bob Crane.

Bob Crane was a TV star from the 70s on a show

that I loved called Hogan's Heroes and it turns out

Bob had a bit of what we think is a sexual addiction.

Willem Dafoe plays John Carpenter, the man who was suspected

ultimately of bludgeoning Bob to death with a camera tripod

and it's definitely a tragic story

but it was an interesting,

especially in the current environment,

and all of its accesses.

Well word is, Colonel, there's gonna be

a surprise inspection.

I don't know about you guys but if there's gonna be

an inspection, I got things to hide.

I got things to hide.

There's gonna be an inspection.

It's kind of an outrageous movie

but one of my favorite films.

My kids are never gonna watch it

but I actually really think that movie is profound

and there's no doubt that it captures the essence

of a struggle that this guy really had.

[Announcer] Richard Hoover, Little Miss Sunshine.

Yeah, that was a movie.

I'm sorry, just having a...

Um, I don't know what to say about that.

Man, that was a good movie.

We can skip around. Yeah, we can skip around.

Huh?

No, no, no but I like that movie.

I'm trying to think of what I do want to talk about.

Let's not skip through the...

That's a hit for God's sakes, let's keep it on for a second.

I'm waxing poetic on a movie that was seen

by about a hundred thousand people,

we finally are at Little Miss Sunshine,

you want to move on?

For God's sakes, I don't got that many of these.

[crew laughing]

[chuckling]

Anyway, what'd you ask about?

That movie was a gift.

Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris had not directed

a movie before, they had done a lot of commercial work.

This movie had been out there, in fact a friend of mine,

David Friendly, first showed me the script

and I was like yeah, seems cool, let's do it

and it just couldn't get its funding together.

Nobody thought there was a movie to be made

and so a year went by, two years went by,

I was a little in touch with John and Valerie

and they were like yeah, we really want to make the movie

'cause this Abigail Breslin's gettin' older

so Abigail was now I think nine, nine and a half,

when we finally shot it.

And she was just so right for that role

for obvious reasons.

The producer, Mark Turtlebaum, I thinK originally just,

I think he just wrote a check for seven million dollars

and that's how we ended up making the movie

but the script was great, it was great.

You know, much better than I realized, honestly,

I read Little Miss Sunshine, I was like yeah, it's good.

I don't know, it seemed good, it seemed smart

and then as we got closer to it and I kind of like,

kind of dove into it again I was like oh my gosh,

this thing is so great, every beat, ever nuance,

the characters, everything and I just,

I knew it was first blush good

but I didn't know it was exceptional.

But it really was and I thought once we got together,

we really had something because John and Val wanted

to do a thing which no one seems to do anymore

in show business called rehearsal so we all got together

in this strange space over in, I don't know,

near Culver City.

Steve and Tony and Alan, the whole gang, we did weird stuff,

it was weird actory stuff, we had little diaries

and we'd write what the other characters thought about us.

We played dodge ball together.

I drove us in that yellow van to the valley to go bowling

and about killed us for the first time.

When we made the movie, I almost killed us another 30

or 40 times, it was the most dangerous movie ever mad

'cause we did all our own driving,

we didn't have stunt people, nobody could afford that.

Come on honey. I'm putting it in gear.

[upbeat music]

Go honey. Come on.

Come on, Olive, run, run.

Come on. Come on.

Sheryl, let's go. [screaming]

[upbeat music] Frank, let's go.

If you saw a red or a yellow van screaming down

the freeway at about 60 miles an hour

with a bunch of cameras in it, it was probably us.

[Announcer] Brigsby Bear, Detective Vogel.

A very kind of imaginative script and I had no idea

how that movie was gonna turn out and it's a little gem.

It's a great little film that captures the spirit

of imagination and creativity.

What's that on your shirt?

It's Brigsby.

Of course.

Detective Vogel is a closeted actor [chuckles]

and he actually is helping James, who's a kidnap victim,

who's kind of adapting to his new freedom,

in making a movie, he wants to make a movie

called Brigsby Bear based upon a movie

that his psychotic captor played by Mark Hamill,

actually, showed him repeatedly when he was a child.

I hope this is all making perfect sense to you at home

who haven't seen the movie because I can't explain it

any clearer than that but it's a great movie,

that's all I can tell ya.

[Announcer] Dr. David Ravell,

Nurse Betty was a wonderful script.

In fact, it won the Golden Globe, I believe, that year.

I was playing a soap opera star opposite Renee Zellweger.

She has developed, say, a strange kind of otherworldly crush

on me and believes that I am a real doctor.

Chris Rock, Morgan Freeman, also in the movie,

directed by Neil LaBute, it's a really, really good movie.

One of my favorites, and I remember them

really having trouble with it,

I remember watching an early cut of Nurse Betty

and saying well that sucks because it just didn't work

and they finally, they found it though

through a lot of work and effort, I think,

and it shows you what can happen editorially.

I also remember because I worked, again, with Renee

not too long ago and we were recounting the fact

that I kind of lost it, it's the only movie I've ever done

in my life where I literally just lost it.

We had a scene where she's in a little nurse's outfit

and we're in a diner and I'm Dr. David Ravell

and I say something and we're on a soap opera now.

There's always a chance, David.

But what about tomorrow and the next day and the next day?

We just lost it.

We lost it completely, I've never laughed so hard

and it was funny at first and as the time went by,

you know you're kind of looking at the crew,

people are looking around and Renee and I

are recognizing that it's kind of past

its expiration point now and we really just need

to shoot the goddamn thing.

I ended up with a C stand with a tennis ball on it

representing Renee Zellweger saying,

Jerry, your eyes look like moon beams,

or whatever the hell the line was

and she did the same for me,

that's the only way we could complete the scene.

We're both mortified by it to this day

but hey man, show business.

[Announcer] Bill Sherpherd, House of Cards.

Great thrill to do it in the sense that it's just

an iconic show and it deserves to have a final season

which was close to not happening.

Credit to Robin Wright for kind of keeping

the train on the tracks.

Also the writers being able to retool this

and I thank MRC and Netflix for taking care of the crew.

This is an incredible crew, you watch that show

and yeah the actors are front and center

but there are so many professionals behind

the camera making it look seamless and incredible.

It was great fun to do it, I've always been a fan

of Diana Lane's, the idea that she would be my sister

and partner in evil seemed great.

We do have kind of a Bob Hope Doris Day thing going on

so to actually flip that upside down

and make us formidable enemies trying

to destroy Claire's life was, I think, pretty effective.

It was great fun to do, I mean they really know how

to create chaos, even more than what's happening

in Washington on House of Cards, it's pretty good stuff.

You know, it's a hard question what you look for

in a character because I'm not looking for anything

when I read a script.

It kind of needs to find me, I feel like,

it's like, I never thought of a a guy capable

of doing that or having that agenda.

This is all, writers are great at this.

But I find that it usually is not my search

to find something, it's reading something

and being surprised.

As time goes on, it gets harder and harder

to, I think, to get surprised but they're still out there

and it's still as exciting as hell

when you find something where you're like oh,

that would be fun.

[upbeat music]
